segment.source: During text entry and editing, spell checking informs the user that a word is misspelled by highlighting it with a red squiggle and providing a way for the user to correct the misspelling.
segment.target: During text entry and editing, spell checking informs the user that a word is misspelled by highlighting it with a red squiggle and providing a way for the user to correct the misspelling.

segment.source: Spell checking and text prediction
segment.target: Spell checking and text prediction

segment.source: Guidelines for spell checking
segment.target: Guidelines for spell checking

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]

segment.source: During text entry and editing, spell checking informs the user that a word is misspelled by highlighting it with a red squiggle and provides a way for the user to correct the misspelling.
segment.target: During text entry and editing, spell checking informs the user that a word is misspelled by highlighting it with a red squiggle and provides a way for the user to correct the misspelling.

segment.source: Important APIs
segment.target: Important APIs

segment.source: IsSpellCheckEnabled property (XAML)
segment.target: IsSpellCheckEnabled property (XAML)

segment.source: Recommendations
segment.target: Recommendations

segment.source: Use spell checking to help users as they enter words or sentences into text input controls.
segment.target: Use spell checking to help users as they enter words or sentences into text input controls.

segment.source: Spell checking works with touch, mouse, and keyboard inputs.
segment.target: Spell checking works with touch, mouse, and keyboard inputs.

segment.source: Don't use spell checking when a word is not likely to be in the dictionary or if users wouldn't value spell checking.
segment.target: Don't use spell checking when a word is not likely to be in the dictionary or if users wouldn't value spell checking.

segment.source: For example, don't turn it on for input boxes of passwords, telephone numbers, or names.
segment.target: For example, don't turn it on for input boxes of passwords, telephone numbers, or names.

segment.source: Spell checking is disabled by default for these controls.
segment.target: Spell checking is disabled by default for these controls.

segment.source: Don't disable spell checking just because the current spell checking engine doesn't support your app language.
segment.target: Don't disable spell checking just because the current spell checking engine doesn't support your app language.

segment.source: When the spell checker doesn't support a language, it doesn't do anything, so there's no harm in leaving the option on.
segment.target: When the spell checker doesn't support a language, it doesn't do anything, so there's no harm in leaving the option on.

segment.source: Also, some users might use an Input Method Editor (IME) to enter another language into your app, and that language might be supported.
segment.target: Also, some users might use an Input Method Editor (IME) to enter another language into your app, and that language might be supported.

segment.source: For example, when building a Japanese language app, even though the spell checking engine might not currently recognize that language, don't turn spell checking off.
segment.target: For example, when building a Japanese language app, even though the spell checking engine might not currently recognize that language, don't turn spell checking off.

segment.source: The user may switch to an English IME and type English into the app; if spell checking is enabled, the English will get spell checked.
segment.target: The user may switch to an English IME and type English into the app; if spell checking is enabled, the English will get spell checked.

segment.source: Additional usage guidance
segment.target: Additional usage guidance

segment.source: Windows Store apps provide a built-in spell checker for multiline and single text input boxes, and elements that have their contentEditable property set to true.
segment.target: Windows Store apps provide a built-in spell checker for multiline and single text input boxes, and elements that have their contentEditable property set to true.

segment.source: Here's an example of the built-in spell checker:
segment.target: Here's an example of the built-in spell checker:

segment.source: the built-in spell checker
segment.target: the built-in spell checker

segment.source: For more info, see the TextBox class.
segment.target: For more info, see the TextBox class.

segment.source: Use spell checking with text input controls for these two purposes:
segment.target: Use spell checking with text input controls for these two purposes:

segment.source: To auto-correct misspellings
segment.target: To auto-correct misspellings

segment.source: The spell checking engine automatically corrects misspelled words when it's confident about the correction.
segment.target: The spell checking engine automatically corrects misspelled words when it's confident about the correction.

segment.source: For example, the engine automatically changes "teh" to "the."
segment.target: For example, the engine automatically changes "teh" to "the."

segment.source: To show alternate spellings
segment.target: To show alternate spellings

segment.source: When the spell checking engine is not confident about the corrections, it adds a red line under the misspelled word and displays the alternates in a context menu when you tap or right-click the word.
segment.target: When the spell checking engine is not confident about the corrections, it adds a red line under the misspelled word and displays the alternates in a context menu when you tap or right-click the word.

segment.source: For JavaScript controls, spell checking is turned on by default for multi-line text input controls and turned off for single-line controls.
segment.target: For JavaScript controls, spell checking is turned on by default for multi-line text input controls and turned off for single-line controls.

segment.source: You can manually turn it on for single-line controls by setting the control's spellcheck property to true.
segment.target: You can manually turn it on for single-line controls by setting the control's spellcheck property to true.

segment.source: You can disable spell checking for a control by setting its spellcheck property to false.
segment.target: You can disable spell checking for a control by setting its spellcheck property to false.

segment.source: For XAML TextBox controls, spell checking is turned off by default.
segment.target: For XAML TextBox controls, spell checking is turned off by default.

segment.source: You can turn it on by setting the IsSpellCheckEnabled property to true.
segment.target: You can turn it on by setting the IsSpellCheckEnabled property to true.

segment.source: \[This article contains information that is specific to Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps and Windows 10.
segment.target: \[This article contains information that is specific to Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps and Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.1 guidance, please download the Windows 8.1 guidelines PDF.\]
segment.target: For Windows 8.1 guidance, please download the Windows 8.1 guidelines PDF.\]
